document.docAuthor: Fontana, Paolo, Buzzetti, Filippo Maria, Mariño-Pérez, Ricardo & García-García, Patricia Lucero
document.docTitle: Insara acutitegmina Fontana, Buzzetti, Marino-Perez and Garcia-Garcia
document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of Tettigoniidae from Mexico (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae; Phaneropterinae; Insarini and Odonturini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of Tettigoniidae from Mexico (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae; Phaneropterinae; Insarini and Odonturini)

taxonomicName.emphasis: Insara acutitegmina Fontana, Buzzetti, Mariño-Pérez and García-García

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Male with short tegmina, about half than hind femur length, narrow with rounded apex. Male cerci subconical, straight, incrassate with small apical tooth.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Insara acutitegmina
n. sp.
male Holotype. Head and pronotum dorsal and left lateral view (1, 2); fastigium of vertex dorsal and left lateral view (3, 4); male terminalia dorsal and left lateral view (5, 6).

subSubSection.paragraph: Female: unknown

Type material.
Male holotype , Mexico , Chiapas. 1.5 km SE San Cristóbal de las Casas, Carr. 190, 2325 m, (
16 ° 37 ’ 51 ’’ N
;
92 ° 31 ’ 59 ’’W
),
13 .XII. 2006
, leg. P. García-García & P. Fontana; same data,
1 male
paratype ; Mexico , Chiapas. Carr. 190, 20 km W of desv. Chincultik (La Trinitaria), 1557 m , (
16 °08’ 24 ’’ N
;
91 ° 57 ’00’’W
),
14 .XII. 2006
, Coll. P. García-García & P. Fontana,
1 male
paratype .
Etymology. The species is named after the morphology of male tegmina, very narrow and acutely ending.

Remarks.
Insara acutitegmina
n. sp.
, known only from Chiapas, Mexico (fig. 44 ), lives in undergrowth (brown morphs) as well in grass habitats (green morphs).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 7–13.
Insara acutitegmina
n. sp.
. Right cercus dorsal and right lateral view (7, 8); fastigium of vertex dorsal and left lateral view (3, 4); male terminalia dorsal and left lateral view (5, 6); male subgenital plate ventral view (9); male right opened tegmina dorsal view (10); male Holotype abdomen dorsal pattern (11); green colour form male paratype left lateral view (12); brown colour form male paratypes left lateral view (13).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Insara oaxacae Fontana, Buzzetti, Mariño-Pérez and García-García
Figs. 14 –30
, 32 ,
44

Diagnosis. Fastigium of vertex in both sexes (less evidently in female) with dorsal surface on three distinct levels; tegmina short, about 3 / 4 than hind femur length, wide, with rounded apex. Male cerci subconical, upcurved apically, with large apical tooth.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–19.
Insara oaxacae
n. sp.
male Holotype pronotum dorsal view and head and pronotum left lateral view (14, 15); female pronotum dorsal view and head and pronotum left lateral view (14, 15); male Holotype terminalia dorsal and left lateral view (18, 19).

FIGURES 20–26.
Insara oaxacae
n. sp.
male Holotype right cercus dorsal and right lateral view (20, 21); Male Holotype subgenital plate ventral view (22); male Holotype fastigium of vertex dorsal and left lateral view (23, 24); female, fastigium of vertex dorsal and left lateral view (25, 26).

FIGURES 27–30.
Insara oaxacae
n. sp.
male Holotype right opened tegmina dorsal view (27); female right tegmen, dorsal view (28); female abdomen apex left lateral view (29); female abdomen apex and dorsal pattern (30).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Male holotype measurements.
Body length 29.3 ; pronotum length 3.3 ; lateral lobe length 2.4 ; hind femur length 21.5 ; tegmen length 15.3 and tegmen width 4.0.
Female measurements. Body length 28.6 ; pronotum length 3.2 ; lateral lobe length 2.4 ; hind femur length 20,1; tegmen length 12.0 and tegmen width 3.7 .

Type material.
Male Holotype , Mexico , Oaxaca. San Juan Tonaltepec, 1741 m , (
17 ° 34 ’02’’ N
;
96 ° 56 ’ 46 ’’W
),
26 .IX. 2009
, leg. I. Castellanos-Vargas; female, Oaxaca. San José del Pacífico, 2325 m , (
16 ° 10 ’ 12 ’’ N
;
96 ° 29 ’ 24 ’’W
),
29 .IV. 2008
, leg. F.M. Buzzetti.

Type depository.
Male Holotype and female, CNIN .
Etymology. The species is named after its known distribution, actually restricted to Oaxaca state in Mexico .

Remarks.
Insara oaxacae
n. sp.
shares some characters with
Brachyinsara
Rehn & Hebard, 1914
, in particular the shape of the fastigium. To date
Brachyinsara
includes only two described species,
B. magdalenae
Rehn & Hebard, 1914
(from Magdalena island in Baja California, Mexico ) and
B. hemiptera
Hebard, 1939
(from California, San Diego County, U.S.A. ). The peculiar characters of these two species preclude assignment of our new species to
Brachyinsara
, although the generic classification of the Insarini is quite complex and needs a major revision. Hopefully, this description will be of some value to future workers studying this group.
Insara oaxacae
n. sp.
is presently known only from two localities in Oaxaca (
Fig. 44
).
